diskutility commands
Here are the key diskutil commands for managing disks and volumes on macOS:

Basic Commands:
- `diskutil list` - Show all disks and partitions
- `diskutil info [disk/volume]` - Display detailed information
- `diskutil mount [volume]` - Mount a volume
- `diskutil unmount [volume]` - Unmount a volume
- `diskutil eject [disk]` - Eject a disk

Formatting/Erasing:
- `diskutil eraseDisk [format] [name] [disk]` - Erase and format entire disk
- `diskutil eraseVolume [format] [name] [volume]` - Erase and format volume
- `diskutil reformat [volume]` - Reformat volume keeping same name

Partitioning:
- `diskutil partitionDisk` - Partition a disk
- `diskutil resizeVolume` - Resize existing volume
- `diskutil splitPartition` - Split partition into multiple volumes

Verification/Repair:
- `diskutil verifyDisk [disk]` - Verify disk structure
- `diskutil verifyVolume [volume]` - Verify volume structure
- `diskutil repairDisk [disk]` - Repair disk
- `diskutil repairVolume [volume]` - Repair volume

Note: Many operations require root/sudo privileges. Always back up data before disk operations.

Use `man diskutil` or `diskutil [command] -help` for detailed usage information.
macos how to delete nix store

To delete the Nix store on macOS, you can follow these steps:

1. First, stop the Nix daemon:
```bash
sudo launchctl unload /Library/LaunchDaemons/org.nixos.nix-daemon.plist
```

2. Remove Nix-related files and directories:
```bash
sudo rm -rf /nix
sudo rm -rf /etc/nix
sudo rm -rf /var/root/.nix-*
rm -rf ~/.nix-*
```

3. Remove the Nix daemon service file:
```bash
/nix/nix-installer uninstall
```

4. Remove Nix users and groups:
```bash
sudo dscl . -delete /Groups/nixbld
for i in $(seq 1 32); do
  sudo dscl . -delete /Users/_nixbld$i
done
```

5. Remove Nix from shell configuration files:
Edit and remove any Nix-related lines from:
- ~/.bash_profile
- ~/.bashrc
- ~/.zshrc
- or other shell config files

6. Optional: Clean up /etc/profile.d:
```bash
sudo rm -f /etc/profile.d/nix.sh
```

7. Optional: Clean up /etc/shells:
Remove the Nix shell entries if present:
```bash
sudo vim /etc/shells
```

After completing these steps, you may want to restart your computer to ensure all Nix-related processes are completely removed.

Note: Make sure to back up any important data before performing these operations.
